article.description: Josh Gonner's driving basket with 2.1 seconds remaining lifted South Carolina to a 69-67 victory over Miami in the first round of the NIT on Tuesday night.
article.headline: Miami rallied in final four minutes
article.linkText: Late basket helps Gamecocks squeak past 'Canes
article.story: COLUMBIA, S.C. (AP) -- South Carolina coach Dave Odom used a bit of restraint in the final seconds, letting Josh Gonner drive the basket instead of calling a timeout. The move paid off as Gonner scored a driving basket with 2.1 seconds left, sending the Gamecocks into the second round of the NIT with a 69-67 victory over Miami on Tuesday night. Every coaching instinct told Odom to call time and set up a play when Gonner moved down the court. Then Odom saw an opening on the left side of the lane. "I bit my lip," he said. "When I saw that lane open up outside a little, I said, 'Let it go.' Turned out right for once." The Gamecocks (16-13) next face Arizona State or UNLV. Those teams play their first-round game Thursday. As time ticked away, Gonner saw things open up after he crossed the foul line and was determined to take it all the way to the basket. "I felt like I was open," Gonner said. "I had my man beat. I put up the shot and fortunately it went in." The Gamecocks (16-13) led most of the game, but Miami moved out to a 64-60 lead after Guillermo Diaz hit a 3-pointer with 3:51 to go. Gonner then hit two foul shots, Carlos Powell tied it with a basket and Rocky Trice completed a three-point play that gave South Carolina a 67-64 lead with 22.7 seconds left. But Miami (16-13) wasn't finished. Robert Hite hit his fifth 3-pointer with 8.5 seconds left, tying the game at 67. Gonner then rushed up court, sprinting past Anthony Harris and leaning in for the game-winning basket. The Hurricanes had one final chance, but Diaz's off-balance 3-point try from the left corner missed the mark. The Gamecocks have performed well in the NIT in the past. Three years ago, the South Carolina topped UNLV on the way to the NIT championship before losing in the final to Memphis. South Carolina was bidding for the NCAA Tournament after upsetting Kentucky last month, improving to 14-8. But the Gamecocks lost five of their next six and ended up in the NIT. Powell thinks the Gamecocks can reach New York City again, where the NIT semis and finals are held. "This is what we call a new season right here," he said. "I don't know when it's going to end, but I hope it's Madison Square Garden." Odom was hopeful the second-round game would be back at the Colonial Center. He promised NIT officials the Gamecocks would double the attendance of 6,307 for the next game. "I feel quite certain of that," Odom said. Odom picked up a win over his former assistant, first-year Miami coach Frank Haith, who was hired by Odom as a Wake Forest grad assistant in 1989. Haith returned to Odom's staff with the Demon Deacons from 1997-2001. He was the South Carolina staff for about a month after Odom took the job four seasons ago, but he left for a job with Rick Barnes at Texas. The two hugged before the game and Odom told his former aide to forget their relationship and concentrate on basketball. When Haith said that wasn't possible, Odom told him, "You better, because I will." Powell led the Gamecocks with 18 points while Tarence Kinsey had 11. Hite topped Miami with 23 points. Diaz had 21 and Harris 14. Diaz and Harris had four 3-pointers each as the Hurricanes finished with a season-best tying 13 from behind the arc. Miami looked like a team headed to the NCAA Tournament a month ago, standing 15-7 in its first season in the Atlantic Coast Conference. But the Hurricanes lost six of their final seven games. "I think this program can do more and should do more," Haith said. "I really believe we can have a top 25-type program. That's my goal, that's my dream."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
